Award.AwardTitle: US Students Participation in the 21st Course of ISCRA in Enrice, Italy August 1-7, 2018.
Award.AbstractNarration:
The International School of Cosmic Ray Astrophysics (ISCRA) is a biannual summer school designed to provide an overview of the field to graduate students and young postdoctoral scholars through both lectures and informal discussions with Particle Astrophysics experts. This is the only regular Particle Astrophysics summer school in the world and it has an excellent history of training future leaders in the field. The 21st ISCRA course will take place in Erice, Italy, from the 1st to the 7th of August 2018. The sessions will include discussions of new experiments, new experimental results and the new understanding of those results, emphasizing the multi-messenger approach to astrophysics. This award will support the participation of US graduate students and young postdoctoral scientists.

The theme of the 21st ISCRA is "Astroparticle physics: yesterday, today, and tomorrow." Topics for discussion will include neutrino astrophysics, gravitational waves, acceleration and interactions of high energy particles and radiation, measurements of cosmic rays and gamma rays, and future space- and ground-based experiments. Proceedings are published to more broadly disseminate the results.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The International School of Cosmic Ray Astrophysics (ISCRA, web page http://laspace.lsu.edu/iscra) had its 21st course at the Erice Ettore Majorana Center for Scientific Culture during August 1-7, 2018.  It had 90 participants. This includes 78 students, seven lecturers, two senior participants, two Co-Directors of the course, Todor Stanev (Univ.  of Delaware), and J?rg Horandel (Radbound University, Netherlands) plus the Course Secretary Mr. Arthur Smith (England). Thirteen of the participants were from US: ten students, two lecturers, and one of the Co-Directors. There were also 21 German participants (2 lecturers and 1 senior participant); six students from Mexico and China; five  students  from the Russian Federation; 4 students each from France and the Czech Republic; 3 participants each from UK (2 lecturers and the Course Secretary), Ukraine, Spain, Japan; 2 participants each from Italy (1 lecturer and 1 senior participant), Algeria, Belgium, Brazil, Canada, Poland, South Africa; and 1 participant each from Netherlands (Co-Director), Switzerland, Slovenia, Romania.

 

The topics of the school included lectures on the cosmic rays, detection and acceleration (J. Horandel, T. Stanev, P.S. Marrocchesi, S. Sarkar, R. Schliskeiser, A. Watson), gravitational waves (G. Gonzalez), IceCube (F. Halzen), and very-high-energy gamma-ray astronomy (C. Stegmann). Forty-one students gave 1/2 hour lectures or presented posters. All lectures have been available after the school at laspace.lsu.edu/ISCRA/. The school ended with a general discussion and evaluation of the school.

 

The 21st session of the School became possible because of the support from the Ettore Majorana Centre for Scientific Culture in Erice, Sicily, and its director, Prof A. Zichichi and from the European Physical Society, the Helmholtz Alliance for Astroparticle Physics, the Niederlands Institute for Radio Astronomy, and Nikhef. The 2018 Course was supported by NSF in the amount of $10,000.

 

This amount was used for the fee of 700 euros each of ten US participants, all of which are graduate students:

Bourbeau James, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI - e700

Diesing Rebecca, University of Chicago, Chicago, IL - e700

Friedman Elizabeth (Liz), University of Maryland, College Park, MD - e700

Khamielwal Rishabh, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI - e700

Liu Qinrui, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI - e700

Lundeen Joseph, Michigan State University, Lansing MI - e700

Muzio Marco, New York University, New York, NY - e700

Remington Jackson, University of Utah - e700

Ryan Aaron, Louisiana State University - e700

Western Emma, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA - e700

 

The school fee covers the participation in the school, transport from Palermo to Erice, lodging, and food. After paying this fee the students do not have to pay for anything. The total amount of 7,000 euro was transferred from the University of Delaware to the Center in Erice from the NSF grant. The approximate total expense (including the transfer fee) was $7,879.20.  The remaining balance of $2,120.80 was returned to NSF.
